title: Federal Reserve Lays Out Its Bond-Buying Outlook; Philippines, Indonesia Central Banks Hold Steady
summary: Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday updated their formal guidance around how long their large-scale purchases of government debt and mortgage securities would continue, complementing their pledge in September that set a higher bar to raise interest rates. The Fed stated the purchases would continue “until substantial further progress has been made” toward broader employment and inflation goals. For his part, Fed Chairman Jerome Powell, speaking after the last Federal Open Market Committee meeting of the year, sounded fairly confident that the Treasury market over the long run could operate without the central bank’s assistance.

Today’s update comes after the Fed said it joined an international effort of central banks and financial regulators aimed at mitigating risks from climate change.

title: New York Fed Finds Households Ready to Spend; Fed’s Look at Climate Change Faces Political Heat
summary: A Federal Reserve Bank of New York survey has found U.S. households reporting the highest level of expected spending growth in four years against a backdrop of expected household income gains holding steady. However, survey respondents “were more pessimistic about their households’ financial situations in the year ahead,” the report says. Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve is starting to face some political pushback for taking up climate-change considerations, Michael S. Derby writes. He notes that some Republicans in Congress are raising concerns about the inclusion of climate-change risks in bank regulation and whether the Fed should join other top global central banks in looking at how to ensure the financial system doesn’t worsen climate change.

title: PE Daily: K1 Nears $3.9 Billion for K5 Fund | TC Latam Sets Up a Credit Arm | Excellere Takes Aim at $750 Million
summary: Senior dealmakers say there’s no rush to get deals done before President-elect Joe Biden occupies the White House, raising prospects for a significant increase in taxes on things such as capital gains and carried interest. But the floodgates seem to have opened not long after the question of who would be in charge next year was effectively settled. The profusion of transactions took off this week, as our reports have shown. But the pickup may just reflect a typical year-end drive to close business that’s been pending, too. Either way, we have a lot for your consideration condensed below.
